profileText: A Representative and a Senator from South Carolina; born in Newberry District, S.C., November 15, 1807; graduated from the South Carolina College (now the University of South Carolina) at Columbia in 1825; taught school and wrote for a newspaper; studied law, admitted to the bar in 1828 and practiced in Columbia; established a newspaper to support nullification; planter; elected as a Nullifier to the Twenty-fourth Congress in 1834 and served from March 4, 1835, until February 26, 1836, when he resigned because of ill health; spent two years in Europe; returned to South Carolina and engaged in agricultural pursuits; Governor of South Carolina 1842-1844; elected as a Democrat to the United States Senate in 1857 to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Andrew P. Butler and served from December 7, 1857, to November 11, 1860, when he withdrew; died at "Redcliffe," Beach Island, S.C., November 13, 1864.

researchRecord.name: 1774-1875 (bulk 1823-1864). 10 linear feet. Correspondence, diaries (1831, 1836-1838, 1841-1846), plantation account books and manuals (1832-1858), scrapbooks, and manuscript and printed copies of speeches chiefly reflecting state and national politics prior to the Civil War. Topics include states' rights, slavery, state banks, the Southern Convention at Nashville in 1850, secession, nullification, and the tariff. Available on 20 microfilm reels. Finding aid.
1831-1845. 12 items. Chiefly about family, plantation matters, politics, and travels. Finding aid.
Ca. 50 items in Mason family and Edmund Ruffin papers. Finding aid.

1785-1939. 5,237 items and 53 volumes. Personal, business, and congressional papers and correspondence. Volumes are selections of poetry, student lecture notes, scrapbooks, letterbook (1831-1833), plantation journal (1831-1887), diary (1836-1837), stud books (1833-1840) regarding horses and their winnings, and personal, travel and plantation account books. Finding aid. Available on microfilm.
Estate papers in Hammond-Bryan-Cumming family papers, 1737-1961; and correspondence in Lewis Malone Ayer papers, 1768-1870. Finding aid.
Ca. 10 items in the John Caldwell Calhoun papers, 1784-1888. Finding aid. Restricted.
21 items in United States Senators' papers, 1779-1946.
